headline: The Whole Story with Anderson Cooper
subHeadline: The Whole Story With Anderson Cooper: Why Springfield? Aired 9- 10p ET

utterances.speaker: FAREED ZAKARIA, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Actually, one that is old and familiar, one marked by narrow nationalism, protectionism, insecurity and constant mass scale violence and war.Thank you for watching this special hour on America First. I'm Fareed Zakaria.

utterances.speaker: ANDERSON COOPER, CNN HOST
utterances.sentences: Welcome to The Whole Story. I'm Anderson Cooper. The city of Springfield, Ohio has become a flashpoint in this presidential election. It's home to roughly 12,000 Haitian immigrants who are residing legally there, most under temporary protected status because of the deteriorating living conditions in Haiti.But these immigrants have been targeted by former President Donald Trump, who promises to deport them if elected, and by his running mate who spread wildly discredited claims and conspiracy theories about the Haitians in Springfield. CNN's Omar Jimenez has been reporting from Springfield, and over the next hour, examines the long history of why immigrants have flopped to this city, including the recent influx of Haitians, and looks at what will happen to the local economy if they leave. (BEGIN VIDEOTAPE)

utterances.speaker: DANEIL AULA, HAITIAN RESIDENT
utterances.sentences: We come to America to work. To save our lives. To take care of our family. Not for doing bad things. We are not bad people. The problem is we can't communicate. As Haitians, we don't speak English. They don't speak Creole. When we can't communicate, we are afraid. But when they have the possibility to know the Haitian community, it will be another thing.ROSS MCGREGOR, PRESIDENT, PENTAFLEX, INC.: Pentaflex was founded in 1972 by my father. What we've always focused on is being able to make very heavy gauged, complex metal stampings and assemblies. We do a lot of work with the commercial vehicle industry. All of our parts that we're making they're safety related and very critical to the breaking operation of heavy trucks.

utterances.speaker: OMAR JIMENEZ, CNN CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Breaks are important.

utterances.speaker: MCGREGOR
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: We need breaks.

utterances.speaker: MCGREGOR
utterances.sentences: That's right.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: When would you say you hired your first Haitian immigrant?

utterances.speaker: MCGREGOR
utterances.sentences: Three, four years ago. Post-pandemic era. As we came out of the pandemic, there was this huge demand for production. And we were struggling to find people to come in and work with us. They might work a day or two and then we'd never see him again. They just would disappear.And that is a real problem when you're running a production facility. You need to have a reliable workforce that you can count on to be at work every day. When you look at who our major employers are right now manufacturing is still a vital part of our economic base. But not everybody wants to come to work every day and run a machine.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: How much more difficult do you think it would have been to scale up your production without the population of Haitians that we had coming here?

utterances.speaker: MCGREGOR
utterances.sentences: I think it would have been more difficult. They came back every day and became very productive as an employee.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: You were telling me you lost an employee because you couldn't offer them overtime.

utterances.speaker: JIM SCIUTTO, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: The Haitian government extended a state of emergency for the entire country due to ongoing deadly gang violence.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: The country now overrun by gang leaders attacking airports, police stations.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: At least 70 people are dead following an attack by gang members in central Haiti. Three infants are among the dead. The U.N. reports at least 3600 people have been killed.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: How long have you been working here at Pentaflex?

utterances.speaker: AULA
utterances.sentences: One year.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Why did you have to leave Haiti?

utterances.speaker: AULA
utterances.sentences: Because my life was not be safe. They burn my house. I lost everything.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Who was after you? Do you know?

utterances.speaker: AULA
utterances.sentences: Because I am a police officer.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: That's the only reason.

utterances.speaker: AULA
utterances.sentences: That the reason.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Do you think you would have been killed if you stayed in Haiti?

utterances.speaker: AULA
utterances.sentences: I know that. There are two friends who let me know that.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: One of the things you told me was that working here sometimes is hard because you don't have your family.

utterances.speaker: AULA
utterances.sentences: Yes. They live somewhere in Haiti right now.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Are they in hiding?

utterances.speaker: AULA
utterances.sentences: Yes, because when a gang or someone who have problem with you knows your family, he can do everything with your family because the family was a partner with a police officer.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Do you talk to your family often?

utterances.speaker: AULA
utterances.sentences: Every day, every day. Sometimes two, three times.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: What do you talk about?

utterances.speaker: AULA
utterances.sentences: Everything. I always want to know always my daughter, my wife.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: How old is your daughter?

utterances.speaker: AULA
utterances.sentences: Last Sunday of September she is 8 years old.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: So you couldn't be there for her birthday?

utterances.speaker: AULA
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Is that hard?

utterances.speaker: AULA
utterances.sentences: Very hard. Very hard. Because she represents my heart. She is my firstborn. She said to me, Papi, never leave me alone. Never leave me alone. Stay with me. I miss you. Sometimes when I remember that, I want to cry but I have to take power, I have to stay strong because I have to take care of them. I have to stay alive because I expect to meet them again.There's different kind of person you meet when you go somewhere. There are some people who look in you the bad way. There are some who always welcome you. Always greet you and say you something, encourage you. When I go to the grocery, I often use some word of joke. That make me feel good when I meet someone. I give to other people a possibility to communicate with me.

utterances.speaker: BRYAN HECK, CITY MANAGER
utterances.sentences: The last several years we've seen more growth than we've seen for decades past. We've seen a revitalization and resurgence of our downtown. Before Bridgewater, which is one of the newer developments, we saw little to no investment in our housing stock for 30 plus years. Originally, that project was planned over five to six years. They've been able to move quicker because the pace of sales and the need for housing.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: What's on the left here?

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: The influx of Haitians has brought a lot of benefits in that some of the economic boom or increase that you were talking about, you have to attribute in some ways to them.

utterances.speaker: HECK
utterances.sentences: That is certainly true. The Haitian community members have been a benefit to our economy, and that benefit to the economy has helped us continue our path of revitalization and growth. We've been successful in creating and bringing new jobs to our community.But you have to have a workforce to be able to work those jobs. And the Haitian community members, they're hard workers. They are working these jobs. I know one company had 50 jobs that just went unfilled for a long period of time until the Haitian community started coming into Springfield. There's the ability to grow and expand our existing businesses and allows us to create new jobs, new companies coming into our market because of that workforce, which then allows us to grow in housing, in retail, in restaurant, and other means for our community.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: And even with this new housing going in, it's still nowhere near enough what you need.

utterances.speaker: HECK
utterances.sentences: No. We were already at a housing shortage with our existing population. We're going to have 2,000 new units built over the next three years in Springfield, Ohio. But with 15,000 new residents that's not going to be enough.We're trying to address those issues that exist in Springfield, Ohio, but when we've been elevated into the national spotlight for the wrong reason, that has not helped. We need help, not hate.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, REPUBLICAN PRESIDENTIAL NOMINEE
utterances.sentences: They're eating the dogs. They're eating the cats. You have to get them the hell out.DIEFF-SONN LEBON, HAITIAN RESIDENT (through text translation): A white man drove by and yelled, Trump.

utterances.speaker: AULA
utterances.sentences: I'm so scared.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: On August 28, 2024, a Springfield resident reported to police that she suspected her Haitian neighbors of chopping up her cat after finding "meat" in the backyard. Soon after, social media posts began circulating about pet-eating Haitians and were even promoted by neo-Nazi groups. Just days after the initial report, the owner's cat "Miss Sassy" was found safety in her basement.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: I've been here multiple times and every time I come back here, it seems like there's more fear, there's for more tension, there's more nervousness about what's going on. Right now we are getting ready to go meet a Haitian immigrant who got here just in the past few years.We met Dieff-sonn at his construction site as he was getting off of work and honestly, we weren't even sure if he wanted his name to be used or if he wanted his face to be shown basically because he was scared like so many of the Haitians we've spoken to here. They were scared about consequences of their names getting out there, of facing potential threats, of essentially being harassed. We were heading out to dinner at a Haitian restaurant in the area, but we made a stop here at essentially what's immigration services for Dieff-sonn. UNIDENTIFIED MALE (through translation): Yes. Yes. Come have a seat. JIMENEZ: He is here legally. But the reason why we wanted to stop here is because he wanted more information how he can protect himself if there is an effort for mass deportation in the future. UNIDENTIFIED MALE (through translation): If a person has received a notice of intention to deport, we can write a motion letter to the judges on his or her behalf.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You look at Springfield, Ohio. They're going in violently. They are dangerous. They are at the highest level of criminality.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHICS
utterances.sentences: Haitians in Springfield are more likely to be the victims of crime than they are to be the perpetrators, according to county data. There were 199 inmates in Clark County jail as of September 8, 2024. Only two of them, representing one percent of the inmates, were Haitian.LEBON (through translation): Two goat dishes. I left Haiti, first of all, because of insecurity reason, and uncertainty. A friend of mine suggested that I move to Springfield. This month makes it a year since I have been living in Springfield.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Did you ever have anybody say something to you personally?LEBON (through translation): As I was walking down the road, a white man drove by and yelled, Trump.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Were you scared when you heard that?LEBON (through translation): Yes, I was scared. Because I was on the street. I was going to buy something. And I was also walking on foot. So I was scared and I hurried to get home.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Had you ever dealt with anything like that before living here?LEBON (through translation): No, no. There were no such thing. It was peaceful here, understand, there were no such things. Everything stared after the remark.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Thank you so much. Thank you, thank you, thank you. OK. OK.LEBON (through translation): This is rice. This is fried pork. And plantains.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: What did you think when you first heard people saying that you're eating cats and dogs here in Springfield?LEBON (through translation): I was very shocked. I had a bad day at work. My colleagues know that I am Haitian. They were asking me questions. I felt ashamed all day long.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Your life changed as soon as those words were said?LEBON (through translation): Well, it really upset me. I left my country because of insecurity, and now even here, I no longer feel safe.

utterances.speaker: HECK
utterances.sentences: I had a call from one of Vance's staffers and I asked, hey, are the rumors true? Are pets being taken and eaten by the immigrants in your community? I said no. It's a baseless claim and then to see that continue to be retweeted by Vance himself the next day, and then sitting there watching the presidential debate to see that that is the light that's being shared on our community. Even though we've told them that it's not true. That's difficult.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: What is the dynamic been like just in this city?

utterances.speaker: HECK
utterances.sentences: A lot of tension. We are living the danger that misinformation and lies creates.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Debunked conspiracy theories sparked violent threats.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: We've had well over 35 different threats, bomb threats.

utterances.speaker: RAFAEL ROMO, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT
utterances.sentences: Those threats have prompted evacuations of elementary schools and supermarkets, lockdowns of hospitals.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: I don't know what happened with the bomb threats. I know that it's been taken over by illegal migrants and that's a terrible thing that happened.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I was at the head of the anti-Haitian immigration march earlier this month. I've come to bring a word of warning. Stop what you're doing before it's too late. Crime and savagery will only increase with every Haitian you bring in. And with it --MAYOR ROB RUE (R), SPRINGFIELD: This just sounds threatening. If you go ahead and just peacefully be removed. Thank you so much.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: These people are really outsiders.

utterances.speaker: RUE
utterances.sentences: You're done. Thank you. That's all. Thank you so much. Not really thank you.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Outside one of the schools, we saw watchtowers that the state has helped install really as an added security measure in the wake of some of the recent threats that we've seen to these schools. Now the threats have ended up being hoaxes but they've resulted in real evacuations of these students and staffs, and bottom line has just disrupted life for so many in this area. HECK

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Has it been scary?

utterances.speaker: AULA
utterances.sentences: I'm so scared because when I was needy, I can go somewhere and I have the same possibility to leave but here I know nothing. I go home and I come to work. A lot of Haitian already leaves Springfield. I have of course then she called me last Sunday and let me know. You don't want to come to live with me.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: AULA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: There are people right now telling you to leave Springfield.

utterances.speaker: AULA
utterances.sentences: Yes. Yes.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Has that ever happened before?

utterances.speaker: AULA
utterances.sentences: No. No.

utterances.speaker: AMANDA PAYEN, HAITIAN AMERICAN RESIDENT
utterances.sentences: Dinnertime. That's real spice.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Did you put the spice right on the oyster?A. PAYEN: Yes, that's what I did.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: I got to do it.A. PAYEN: Let's see how you do it.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Ready? One, two, three.A. PAYEN: One, two, three.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Definitely have a little bit of a kick. But it's perfect.How long have you been in the U.S.?

utterances.speaker: JACOB PAYEN, HAITIAN AMERICAN RESIDENT
utterances.sentences: I have been in the U.S. for over 29 years now. She has been here for about, what?A. PAYEN: Nine to 10 years. J. PAYEN: Nine to 10 years.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Yes. A lot of people, you know, have been, you know, especially in the Haitian community, think tense has been the word that people have been using. I mean, it sounds like you all have felt that.A. PAYEN: We are Haitian-American. We're part of the country. We're part of the city. We are citizen American. So I don't see that makes any sense for other American hurting, American people.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: What have the past few weeks been like for you?A. PAYEN: Overwhelming since, you know, I'm wondering what's going on in my son's head right now. J. PAYEN: And we try to stay away from topics such as Haitians eat this, Haitians eat that. Because they've been getting picked on at the school.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Wow.J. PAYEN: It's going to leave a scar, somewhere in our lives for a long time. This is one of our favorites.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Well, thank you guys for talking to me over eating. That spies got to me on the chip by the way. So I was -- I was struggling on that last one. I was like, OK, stay serious. I got to --J. PAYEN: If there's one thing I want to say, there's a little boy last year on his way on the first day of school, on his way to school he got -- his school bus get into an accident.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Yes.J. PAYEN: And the driver behind the other wheel was a Haitian immigrant and that little boy died. We want to send out our sympathy to the Clark's family. I want to make that clear. A. PAYEN: And we are sorry. And we are -- J. PAYEN: And we are deeply sorry for the loss. Mr. Clark understand it was an accident. He understands that.

utterances.speaker: DANA BASH, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: It was a car accident involving a Haitian immigrant.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: 11-year-old Aiden Clark was killed. KATE BOLDUAN, CNN ANCHOR

utterances.speaker: NATHAN CLARK, FATHER OF AIDEN CLARK
utterances.sentences: They can vomit all the hate they want about illegal immigrants. The border crisis. And even untrue claims about fluffy pets being ravaged and eaten by community members. However, they are not allowed nor have they ever been allowed to mention Aiden Clark from Springfield, Ohio.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You have to remove the people. You cannot destroy -- we cannot destroy our country. They have to be removed.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: CBS News vice president debate. We want to welcome our viewers on CBS.

utterances.speaker: VANCE
utterances.sentences: Look, in Springfield, Ohio, and in communities all across this country we brought in millions of illegal immigrants to compete with Americans for scarce homes.J. PAYEN: This is not what it's about.

utterances.speaker: VANCE
utterances.sentences: Are the American citizens who have had their lives destroyed by Kamala Harris' open border.A. PAYEN: You destroyed our lie.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Just to clarify for our viewers, Springfield, Ohio, does have a large number of Haitian migrants who have legal status temporary protected.J. PAYEN: Legal. A. PAYEN: Legal. Yes.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: What do you all remember about coming here as teenagers?GOV. MIKE DEWINE (R), OHIO: We started dating and state theater right up here was one place we went. You know, 12 miles from our house and Springfield was kind of the place we went to for dates.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: So when you were in high school, he was trying to impress you still at this point by bringing you to Springfield?

utterances.speaker: DEWINE
utterances.sentences: Are you impressed?

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Is it similar to what it was like when you first walk through these doors? DEWINE

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: What has this past month been like?

utterances.speaker: DEWINE
utterances.sentences: Well, it's been kind of strange, you know. We have been working with the community for some time.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Look, yes, you're governor of Ohio, but you were also born in Springfield. You've been to Haiti many, many times, you and your family have also helped stand up a school down there in Haiti as well.

utterances.speaker: DEWINE
utterances.sentences: Our schools in Cite Soleil, which is always the poorest and the worst area. They're educating about 5,000 kids every single day.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: And all of these things sort of come together in, as you described, a strange way. What was your reaction when former President Trump flat-out said in Springfield, patients are eating the cats and dogs?

utterances.speaker: DEWINE
utterances.sentences: Well, as governor, I have an obligation to tell the truth and talk about Springfield. We knew that's not true. No evidence of that at all.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: I've spoken to a lot of Haitians and one of the things that I've heard from all of them is they're scared in a way that they haven't been before.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: This isn't the first time we've seen a wave of immigrants here.

utterances.speaker: DEWINE
utterances.sentences: If you look at Springfield's history by 1870, the African American population in Springfield, only five years after the civil war, was about 10 percent. So you had clearly some freed slave coming before. You had some who escaped. Well before the big migration that we always talk about in the 1900s.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Springfield really does have a storied immigration history. I mean, this was a stop on the underground railroad, so Springfield was really a symbol of a step toward freedom but also a new life for slaves in America.And then Greeks immigrated here in the early 1900s. That's when we saw some of the first Greek establishments created here. Germans, Irish, Hispanics later on, and now we're seeing an influx of Haitian immigrants. DEWINE: If you look at Springfield's growth in the last few years, that's been fueled a lot of it by the Haitian immigrants who are taking jobs that were open and they couldn't be filled by someone. I had one employer look me in the eye and said, I don't think our company really would be here today if it wasn't for Haitians. I've had other people say we wouldn't have been able to go to the second shift. Others said we wouldn't be able to take on new business. Pumping resources into the communities is how communities grow.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Do you think Springfield will ever be the same? You have to get them the hell out. You have to get them out. I'm sorry. Can't have it. Can't have it. They've destroyed it.

utterances.speaker: AUDIENCE
utterances.sentences: Send them back. Send them back. Send them back.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: You have to remove the people. We cannot destroy our country. They have to be removed.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED REPORTER
utterances.sentences: So you would revoke the temporary protected status?

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: Absolutely I'd revoke it and I'd bring them back to their country.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: If we did wake up the next morning and all of the Haitians here were gone, what do you think happens to Springfield?

utterances.speaker: DEWINE
utterances.sentences: That's not good for Springfield. I would not like to see them gone. I think it'd be bad for Springfield. I think it'd be bad for Ohio.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: You've voted for Donald Trump in 2020. He is now saying that if he is re-elected, he's going to deport these Haitian immigrants. I mean, do you still plan to vote for him?

utterances.speaker: DEWINE
utterances.sentences: I think it would be a mistake to kick these people out.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Not enough of a mistake to change how you plan to vote?

utterances.speaker: DEWINE
utterances.sentences: Well, look, I think the decision to who you support for president is based upon multiple issues, and I am a Republican. I support my party. Going against the nominee of the party I think, you know, makes me a less effective governor of the state of Ohio.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Given that, what do you say to a Haitian who will see these comments and say I thought this governor had my back, and he is now going to support the person who wants to kick me out?

utterances.speaker: DEWINE
utterances.sentences: Yes. Look, people can make any conclusion they want to, but I make my position very, very clear. I don't think they should be thrown. I think it would be a dramatic mistake. I think it's wrong.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: There's a disconnect between sort of the national politics of things versus the reality of what's going on here.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED RESIDENT
utterances.sentences: They don't understand. We need an interpreter. We need somebody here to help them because there's a language barrier, there really is.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED RESIDENT
utterances.sentences: The influx here has been a culture shock, you know, to say the least.

utterances.speaker: RUE
utterances.sentences: We didn't get a chance to have an infrastructure in place. The most frustrating thing is we've got to spend tax dollars to try to take care of 15,000 more folks every year and make sure that everybody has a safe environment to be in.

utterances.speaker: HECK
utterances.sentences: Some of the Haitian migration started as far back as 2014 but really the last three years is when we've seen the largest surge in our Haitian migrant population. It's important for us that we're able to embrace this new change for our community and I will say it hasn't come easy, you know. People fear change. Change is tough.

utterances.speaker: HECK
utterances.sentences: In the state of Ohio, anybody over the age of 18 does not have to go through a formal driver's education program. They can test for their license and they can begin driving. There has been issues as it relates to driving and our new Haitian neighbors acclimating to --

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Road signs.

utterances.speaker: HECK
utterances.sentences: Road signs and roadways that they didn't experience in Haiti.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: And you have some weird streets.

utterances.speaker: HECK
utterances.sentences: We do. We have one way streets right downtown and we have some weird different directions that you have to go.J. PAYEN: I have to be honest with you. Let me be honest on this one.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Go for it.J. PAYEN: We have bad driving records here in Springfield. It causes car insurance to go up. That has been one of the problems. JIMENEZ: Yes. J. PAYEN: It becomes frustrating.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: When you talk about schools, they too have struggled with the influx of these Haitian immigrants because when you have a large amount of students coming into a school district like this they've been trying to find a number of translators to match up.

utterances.speaker: HECK
utterances.sentences: They went from less than 100 English language learners to now they have served over 1,200. And that's tough.

utterances.speaker: MCGREGOR
utterances.sentences: The language barrier was a steep, steep hill to climb. We've helped them find English as a second language classes.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: What you're seeing the last few years you guys have now -- the instructions aren't just in English but they're in Creole as well?

utterances.speaker: MCGREGOR
utterances.sentences: Exactly. A lot of the Haitians here in Springfield have become much better at the English language.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: You're going to an English class after this, right, as I understand?

utterances.speaker: AULA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Why has that been so important to you?

utterances.speaker: AULA
utterances.sentences: I have an objective since I was in Haiti. I want to integrate this society that the reason I go to the English class to have more knowledge in the English and to learn something and to be better for the community.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: What do you need to support the population that you have now?

utterances.speaker: HECK
utterances.sentences: Health care, our health care is strapped for resources right now. We have our federally qualified health center. They're going to spend $600,000 over the next year on translation services alone.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: HECK
utterances.sentences: Instead of that money going towards actual health care services, they're having to go towards translation services. And that's a challenge.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: This is a mobile healthcare clinic the state has helped put up essentially to try and target some of the pressure points we've seen in the health care system here. So those are things like blood pressure screenings, vaccinations, things of that nature, and state officials say they've already seen close to 100 patients in just about a week's time, which well exceeded their expectations.

utterances.speaker: HECK
utterances.sentences: Back in July I sent a letter to Senator Brown and then CC Senator Vance on that letter. And it was to highlight the housing crisis. I didn't call it a migrant crisis. I didn't call it an immigration crisis. It's a housing crisis. And the fact that the pace of growth for our community is just -- was not sustainable and continues to not be sustainable unless we get some additional support from the state and federal government.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: How have you approached adding resources from a state perspective to here in Springfield?

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: From the federal government, you think?

utterances.speaker: DEWINE
utterances.sentences: Well, the community needs it. Where it comes from is a different issue. I mean, we've also of course reached out to the federal government.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: I do think it's fair to say that, you know, we know prices have gone up the past few years. Economics have gotten tougher for a lot of individuals, nonimmigrants here in Springfield. I mean what do you say to some of those who say, well, so much attention is going to the Haitians. What about me?

utterances.speaker: DEWINE
utterances.sentences: Everything that we have done has been for every citizen in Springfield. I don't care whether they're Haitian or whether they've been in Springfield for five generations.

utterances.speaker: LEBON
utterances.sentences: I love all of them. Even the people hate me, angry about me, I love them.

utterances.speaker: VANCE
utterances.sentences: The American media totally ignored this stuff until Donald Trump and I start talking about cat memes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But it wasn't a meme.

utterances.speaker: VANCE
utterances.sentences: If I have to create stories so that the American media actually pays attention to the suffering of the American people, then that's what I'm going to do, Dana.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Sorry, you just said that you're creating the story.

utterances.speaker: VANCE
utterances.sentences: What's that, Dana? Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: So the eating dogs and cats thing is not accurate?

utterances.speaker: VANCE
utterances.sentences: We are creating -- we are -- Dana.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: So we're headed into this Haitian grocery store. But honestly, it's so much more than that. Mainly because of the woman who runs it. And this is where we find the lovely Philomene.How are you doing? Come on out here. (Speaking in foreign language).

utterances.speaker: PHILOMENE PHILOSTIN, HAITIAN AMERICAN RESIDENT
utterances.sentences: (Speaking in foreign language).

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: (Speaking in foreign language).

utterances.speaker: PHILOSTIN
utterances.sentences: (Speaking in foreign language).Let me tell you something, don't let nobody intimidate you. If you believe in yourself, you are a hard worker, what people say, you don't have to worry about it. You just have to do your best of you. That's it. I'm not worried. I know I don't eat dog. I don't eat cats so I don't have to worry if somebody told me I eat dog. Did you ever eat dog?

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: PHILOSTIN
utterances.sentences: OK. So you don't have to be worried. Somebody says something because you're not happy, everybody is just leave. No. Stop it. No, you're not going nowhere. You got to stay. If you're New York, wherever you go, you cannot be the same thing. Somebody says something, you just grab more, no. Stop it. That piss me off.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: You've been here in the U.S. 30 years you said?

utterances.speaker: PHILOSTIN
utterances.sentences: 30. Yes. I've been citizen over 25 years. We opened the shop, you know, everything was good, you know, until whatever happened people start moving out. A lot of people moving. A lot of --

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: A lot of Haitians are moving.

utterances.speaker: PHILOSTIN
utterances.sentences: A lot of -- that was kind of what make me mad. Why we have to be moving because somebody says something?

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Have Haitians been scared here?

utterances.speaker: PHILOSTIN
utterances.sentences: They do scare. That's why they're moving. The guy said they're going to come and shoot them. They're going to come in do this, do that. So they're really worried. Some people are really worried to come shopping.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: Yes, you were saying your business has slowed down.

utterances.speaker: PHILOSTIN
utterances.sentences: They're very slow. Me, I'm not worried about that because I see that before.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: You seem like a fighter. You seem like, you know what, I'm not going to let them bring me down.

utterances.speaker: PHILOSTIN
utterances.sentences: I am strong. I think it's the nature. As a woman, a single woman, who raise my three kids, and then I work hard. Number one, I am not afraid of nobody. I am not. I actually have people that was following me over 15 minutes even when I reach a police on the street. So I tell them that, I still not scared.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: My main concern, I'm a youth leader. And I've been doing that for 10 years. What is kind of sad for me and I say it with the bottom of my heart, that is too much for the kids.

utterances.speaker: JIMENEZ
utterances.sentences: What's been going on right now is too much for the kids.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Yes. It is too much for the kids. You know, the kids get bullied on in school. Some other kids call them name. Everything like that. So when somebody play with the kids you play with me, too. That's my heart. Because I may forget what you say, the kids will never forget what you tell them.Everybody come here. We're going to play. Come, come, all the kids. Come in. Get up in here. Get up. Let's get in together. Make a big circle. OK. Song 23rd, one, two, three.
